Been here several times for the past few years; always easy to be seated without much of a wait. Definitely on the smaller end but feels quite comfortable to be seated and chat for an hour or two without being rushed. Left with a great impression every time. Food and service was both great. However this very last time we've been here we were served the free appetizers like the kimchi/pickles/cold salad but it's not really a big deal.

We got takeout from here and every was pretty average. The spicy pork bibimbap had very little meat in it.  Tteok-bokki was just ok and quite bland. The only real saving grace here was the wings-- we got soy garlic, but they weren't that saucy which is how I like.

I've been to kook once before pre covid and tried the scallion pancake, cocktail drinks, scottish egg, and bibimbap. This time I got takeout and tried the Korean fried chicken wings and the cold noodles. It came with only one side dish though which was a little disappointing. The side dish was a potato salad. I really liked the chicken wings!! They were super crispy and crunchy but not oily at all. It also had a small container of pickled radish. The cold noodles were really good too and they had a container of the broth with ice in it. Easy to combine together and enjoy delicious Korean cold noodle. Also came with two tiny containers containing vinegar and a mustardy sauce. Highly recommend the Korean fried chicken here!!!
A hole in the wall in east village! Decent Korean food! The ribs were HUGE and well fried! Food's definitely on the heavier side, but very filling!

I was craving good Korean ddukbokki and decided to try this place based on good reviews.  The dish was very good: chewy rice cakes cut into slightly longer pieces, well balanced spicy sauce, a hard boiled egg, and onions.  It would have been better had the fish cake pieces been more plentiful.  The delicious banchan included crunchy delightful kimchi and tasty potato salad.

We almost walked by this place without even noticing it. It's such a tiny little place but after seeing some of the reviews we decided to give it a try. We noticed they had a happy hour menu and decided to try the Korean Fried Chicken Wings with a bottle of soju, a vegetable Sun DuBu JiGae, the Vegetable GimBap, and a KimChi JjiGae. The GumBap was so fresh and amazing. The JiGae was also exactly what we needed since it was so gloomy outside and was even better with some rice. I had never tried Korean Fried Chicken and the one here did not disappoint. They had many flavors but we decided to take their recommendation and do the Spicy Soy flavor. They were crispy and juicy and Perfectly seasoned. It ended up coming out to $81 which was not too bad. The service was really great and if you're looking for a low key place with amazing food this place would be great. The only thing we found odd was that the BanChan were $3... didn't get photos of the rest of the food because we were so hungry but it was all amazing!

A favorite spot for casual hangout with friends and coworkers. The food is incredible, everything is affordably priced, and the vibes are super chill and laid back. Absolutely a hidden gem in the village!

I'd come back to try other dishes on the menu. Recommend!

Service was mediocre but kimchi was good. I don't know when it became a thing for kimchi to become sweet but the fermented kimchi here is how it should be. Sour and refreshing, unlike other places where it's just sweet and tasteless. It's like Koreans are desecrating the flavor of kimchi for non-Koreans or the younger generations that can't handle the fermented sour flavor.

They take it walk ins, great option for non-meat eaters, and the restaurant accommodations large groups. I went with a party of four and from the appetizer to entre it was worth the price. Good portion size and very inexpensive if you go get the ribs so good!

We had the GoChuTwiGim which are tempora stuffed peppers - so so good. For not too expensive you can stuff yourself with Korean Classics - perfect amount of spice. Took the pic after we already ate it looked better before haha
Ordered the Bibimbap with chicken for takeout and the portion size was great, the food was delicious, and it also came with great side dishes!

Korean food is my weakness - especially kimchi sundubu! K'OOK has always been on my bookmark list, and one rainy Sunday afternoon I didn't feel like making the trek to Ktown for my favorite sundubu at BCD.  Their Corn Corny Corn ($5 - hehe to the name) was a nice cheesy little appetizer, but could have had a bit more corn in it.  The sundubu ($13 - you have the option of choosing seafood, beef, mushroom, vegetable or kimchi ... all comes with zucchini, onion & mushroom) was pretty good, but I like mine spicy and it was mild (that's just a personal preference though).  It was loaded more so with veggies than soft tofu, but that's not a complaint either!  Think the soup could have had a bit more flavor...doesn't compare with my all-time favorite BCD, but was still a pretty good sundubu!  Will have to come back and try their Crispy Rice Egg sometime!

During the Phase 2 opening of NYC, I decided to give outdoor dining a try and so I came to K'OOK for an excellent experience. They have revamped the outside to include outdoor seating with partitions and spaced tables. They even put out nice plants for you to look at and made it a real restaurant experience. The waitress was extremely nice and friendly and started me off with appetizers and drinks. The Pinot noir I got was very good. The appetizers were great as well, plus you can never complain about complimentary appetizers. I got the fried egg as an appetizer as well and it exceeded my expectations, and was priced very fair. It was covered in spicy mayo which I love, and the egg was cooked very well. For dinner I got a beef Bibibop, which came in a bowl with a side of rice for me to add in. Although I'm used to it already mixed in with the sauce, I liked that you can add your own sauce so you can measure for yourself how much you want. They did a great job of social distancing and re-opening the restaurant. I will sure be back, and plan to support small local East village restaurants like K'OOK.

Please go, you will not regret it! I've been to K'OOK three times, all during the pandemic, and have been amazed each time. The food is incredible and the prices are amazing for how much food you get. Their outdoor seating is comfortable, I didn't feel too close to other people. They also have multiple heaters for when it's cold out, which is great during the crazy winter weather! They start you out with some complimentary appetizers of kimchi, potato/macaroni salad, bean sprouts, and greens. I've had their noodle soup, chicken wings, bibimbap, friend rice egg, and soju cocktails and everything was incredible. The chicken wings are simply amazing, we had them with the soy garlic sauce and they were the best wings I've ever had. You have to check this place out if you're interested in Korean food, I am so glad I found it and I will definitely keep coming back!

I don't even know who's tasteless soul was cooking that Wednesday night, but our dishes were lacking in every way and service was a whole other issue. Let's start with the scotch egg, which is responsible for 1 star. You can get a scotch egg at every other pub in NYC- this one had spicy Mayo on, it wasn't mind blowing but compared to the rest - it was one of the 2 better items. The star was one of the ban Chan sides- Mexican achiote in a Korean dressing, this earned them their 2nd star. So, that makes 2 of the stars given to food that isn't even Korean. I ordered the ox bone marrow soup- the marrow was invisible and the soup looked like murky dishwater and Tasted like it too. To give it flavor, I was given salt. Lol no amount of salt could have fixed it and I tried. My friend ordered the spicy beef soup which came with dry, over-cooked meat and lackluster flavor, but my friend shared since mine was gross. We couldn't get a refill on water until the end of our meal, good thing my friend came with a bottle of water and napkins bc apparently that's hard to come by at K'ook. The soju flight came out with the food and one tasted like a lemon drop shot and another like a green jolly rancher shot, the lychee and whatever the other one was were less than stellar and I'm not even sure there was Soju in any of them. Don't waste your time or money, so many gems in the area- this isn't one of them.

The only reason why I wanted to come here was because of their crispy rice egg which was very filling! I don't think I'll be coming back anytime soon.

There are not a lot of Korean restaurants that impress me anymore because the food menu is more or less the same. However, I look forward to going back to K'OOK because their menu is slightly different and it reminds me of a family-run Korean restaurant that I ate at Syracuse recently where the foods are homely and good.

Only "complaint" would be I wish it were crunchier (I'm used to bonchon crunchy but maybe because the chained Korean fried chickens use more batter). It was still very good nonetheless. Pork belly - very tasty and juicy, wish the slices were thicker. Scotch egg - mmm crunchy and very satisfying. Galbijjim - flavor was definitely there, I wish it came with more than just 3 pieces (for $18). The meat was somewhat tender and had a bite to it, with that said...I'm used to and prefer my Galbijjim meat more tender and in thicker/stickier stew. I'm a fan of tea infused alcohol so I ordered the earl grey infused soju. I think it needed some sugar in the mix. Although I tasted the refreshing earl grey tea flavor...it was very bitter combined with the soju which made it hard to enjoy. The service was great and the staff was very friendly!

I really enjoyed the deep fried rice balls and flavored soju. The apple & grape flavor is a must-try!! The army base soup was also pretty good and the portion was very generous. This place is moderately priced compared to other Korean restaurants in the city.

I don't want to write too much because I hate that I even wasted my time to eat at this place, but let me explain the 1 star rating. As a Korean, seeing that this place was Korean-owned and had basic Korean dishes, I thought it'd be a fine easy meal with my boyfriend. Little did I know it would be the lowest quality and least tasty Korean food of my life. I was legitimately shocked at the flavorless soondubu and "Dynamic Bowl." The banchan (or "side dishes") were also not properly seasoned. I was literally shocked that a Korean-owned restaurant could sell such food, and not be embarrassed to be profiting off of something that is such a misrepresentation of Korean flavor. Also, the service was below average, with the waitress bumping into me several times and dropping my chopsticks off the table twice. I am so upset that I ate even one bite of this food. If you are looking for Korean food in East Village, PLEASE DO NOT GO HERE, PLEASE GO SOMEWHERE ELSE IN THE ST. MARKS AREA. I'm truly embarrassed as a Korean that this restaurant could be someone's understanding of "Korean food."
The food here is incredible. We also had a wonderful waitress, who was patient and extremely helpful in helping us order. I highly recommend the Crispy Scotch Egg. It's absolutely amazing.

K'OOK is a real gem. I have dined in and ordered delivery from K'OOK at least 10 times. Their food is consistently excellent. Their kimchi jigae is actually rich and spicy -- a rarity in Manhattan. Overall K'OOK nails it on flavor. Definitely one to put in your rotation.

I'm so glad to have found this hidden gem! The food is basically Korean comfort food. I brought my boyfriend here for his birthday and we were both impressed with the food! We decided to share the famous scotch egg, which had a nice crunch on the outside, chewy on the inside with the korean rice and that egg just added good texture to it. What a good mix with the spicy mayo as well. We also tried the soy garlic wings which was really crispy on the outside. At this point I was impressed with the food and when the ox bone soup (unseasoned) came out and we tried that, I knew I found my go to place. This place had all the Korean food I want to eat at a really reasonable price! The only thing I wasn't a fan of was the cheesy rice cake dish. The sizzling platter made the cheese melt to the point of just oil everywhere especially since there were slices of hot dog. Not very appetizing. But overall a very good experience. Service was terrific but at the time I went (Monday, 5:30PM) there were no one there, so I can't complain about service.
I really love this place!  I just got my order and was given my food early and with a smile.  The food is always really great.

Went in for a second visit on Sunday 4/19/15. This time I got the dynamic stone bowl($12) and my friend got the goon mandu($5) which comes with 4 dumplings, and the crispy rice egg($3). I enjoyed my bowl, however my friend was a bit surprised at the serving size of the dumpling order. They are 4 relatively small sized dumplings so don't expect to get full off of it. Taste wise, I believe it was ok but my friend said he wished it was a bit more meaty with less sweet potato noodles inside. The thing about the crispy fried egg was that it was noticeably smaller than the last time we came in. We weren't sure if we just got it big last time, or if this time it came smaller. Consistency is something I would suggest. We also checked in on yelp and got the free dak twigim and this time we tried the soy garlic which was alright, but we definitely preferred the hot and spicy much more. We also heard about the flavored soju and wanted to try that and were able to get samples. We tried the peach flavored soju and I would highly recommend it. Doesn't taste watered down like i was expecting and was surprising good (if you're a soju or vodka fan, get it). If the restaurant ambiance was a bit more upbeat and loud I would def come here and get it with some side dishes. The wait staff and owner was again on point and no issue there. Always around asking how things are making sure everything is ok. Overall pleasant experience.

This is a small spot that is a few steps down from street level. I came with my friend because we did not want to travel so far to ktown and wanted some korean food. We ordered a crispy rice egg, corn corny corn, and dynamic stone bowl. The crispy rice egg was pretty good. It is boil egg wrapped in meat and rice and deep fried. The contrast in textures with the crunchy shell and the soft egg was great. The Dynamic stone bowl I got is with some sort of radish kimchi, spinach, bacon, cheese, and egg in a sizzling pot with rice. The kimchi was actually really salty so luckily there was the rice and spinach to balance everything out or else it would have been unbearable. As for the corn, it was really nothing special.. corn, cheese, peppers, and onions.. something that anyone can make at home. Also to note they do give 4 different banchans and if you want to refill them, u need to pay (I believe). Which is kind of weird to me because korean places usually refill side dishes for free but I guess it's not your average korean place. I think I need to find some time to come back and try the stews to see how they are. I like the family owned feel korean restaurants but there aren't any available in lower manhattan. But from what I had today, I give it 3 stars.

Such an adorable spot located in the east village area. This would be a cute place to bring a date. I  finally get to try the scotch egg after hearing so much about them. I was not disappointed, It was delicious! You absolutely have to try it, it is that good. The braised pork belly (soft dwaeji) was pretty too. Warning, it is pretty fatty/heavy so you might get overwhelmed after a few bites. so take it slow. I also ordered the army stew (budae jjigae), it was pretty disappointing to say the least. It was overly salty and spicy. I had less than 5 bites and my throat was hurting from the amount of salt and spice from the stew. My boyfriend ordered the dynamic stone bowl, he too was dissatisfied with his entree. The rice bowl was covered by a mountain of greens and when its mixed with the rice, the raw salad added an unpleasant bitter taste to the dish. I had high hopes for this place, but sadly it didn't live up to the expectation. I would return for the appetizers, only.

It wasn't terrible but nothing outstanding. Wanted to like the place because who doesn't love korean with a modern twist. Dislike it when I recommend a new place to friends and it becomes a letdown.

I like that this has a chewier texture and filled with dried shrimps, scallion and other things that just makes it soo yummy. Really can't beat the price either. I eat one and am stuffed.

Cash only. $2.50 for a hak roll. You order at a small little window in the shop and it's takeaway only. The layers of rice noodle are filled with savory toppings. One of those is not quite enough for a meal, but two would have been plenty. Great price and great taste!

Coming here on the nostalgic excitement that there is a food spot that was able to bring back the glory of old Chinatown establishment, South Wind, I really wanted to like the food. I am not sure if the excitement led to unreasonable expectations, The Hak Rolls are my personal favorite of the three items on the menu. The texture and flavor of the meat are on point. However I found the pork in the Hak Tofu and filling in the Dumplings to be too sweet. The dumpling skin was really thick but i didn't mind the chewiness. All in all, 3 stars for the effort and Hak Rolls with room for improvement for the dumpling and tofu that everyone seem to be fine with.

I've had a lot of rice rolls and these were good, but not my favorite if I'm being honest. The rice sheets are on the thicker side. Different than anything I've had before. I liked the abundance of filling and green onions. I'm used to more saucy rice rolls so these felt a bit dry. They did have hot sauce. Similar to sriracha. Overall, not my favorite and preference but still a solid place. And for the price, I'm really not complaining. Just not sure if I would go out or my way!

I really enjoyed the food over at Hak Box, but the menu is limited to only three items: rice noodle rolls ($2.50), stuffed tofu ($5/2pcs), and dumplings ($3/4pcs). On the bright side, you can sample everything for only $11. The most memorable of the three, in my opinion, is the rice noodle rolls. Unlike the Cantonese-style cheong fun, the rolls at HakBox are firmer in texture and more robust in flavor and size. The rice noodle base is dotted with salted pork and dried shrimp, rolled into a thick tube and topped with a scallion-oil garnish. Pure rustic, comfort food that is emblematic of Hakka cuisine-- intensely savory, filling, and delicious!

A great hole in the wall serving takeout of traditional cold rolled rice noodles topped with minced pork, dried shrimp, scallions. This authentic and humble dish is done right and if you are in the area looking for a filling snack that is actually "real" chinese food you should definitely stop in.

Saw this pop up on yelp as I'm visiting NYC for the weekend. So glad I tried it! The hak rolls were pretty filling and the hak dumplings were filled well. Their filling is pretty different from average dumplings I've tried. It has a pretty large sign outside, but the interior was quite small. The decor was cute and simple. Only thing was it was cash only. Fairly priced for what you're getting. Great on the go meal. I would definitely stop by if you get a chance!

These rolls are so tasty! Soft, supple rice noodle sheets filled with dried shrimp and ground pork and scallions? What. A. Dream.

Once I heard about this little place that was making food that I grew up with at old South Wind I had to try and they didn't disappoint. The Hak Roll was on point and made fresh which I highly recommend plus the dumplings tasted like the good old days. The tofu with meat filling was great too and although I thought it was undercooked, I was mistaken because it wasn't pink and the texture was supposed to be a little gooey but the owner or manager Warren was really nice about it and gave me a brand new one immediately which shows great customer service. Only thing I wish could be better is if the store was bigger so they can cook even more even though the wait was well worth it.

This place has the best rice noodle rolls ever. They are not chintzy with the fillings and the rolls are big. But there's a steep price to pay for them. $2.50 each. But they are really good. Tons of shrimp, scallions, sesame seeds, etc. it's filling. I highly recommend this place to those who have a fondness for these rolls. This place apparently has only been open a few months. Their rolls apparently sell out by 4 so don't wait too late in the day to get them.

unfortunately I wasn't impressed with the rice roll or dumplings... so far the worst rice roll I've had in Chinatown thus far.... Mine was served cold with only hot sauce as a condiment... it wasn't inedible but just not worthy of a return trip ... dumplings were just boring as well

You would never guess this well rolled up nice sized noodle bundle is actually soft enough with the prefect bit firmness. It is not very salty, which I prefer but to others, ask to see if the nice gentleman will give you more sauce. It is your classic oily grease spoon comfort food, so please be considerate this is not a dieter's snack. For me one was plenty as a meal but I think if I was hungry I need to add an order of tofu, which I will try next time. FYI it is not located on E. Broadway it shares 88 E. Broadway's building but it is a small storefront located on the side on Forsyth Street. Give it a try, old school Chinese food, my uncles and aunts eats these for breakfast, lunch, snack...The service was friendly and quick.

These Cheung fung rolls are absolutely deliciously. So cheap too, two rolls will fill you up. Lots of fillings and a hidden gem in Chinatown. You can even ask them to cut it up so you can share bite size pieces!

I remember eating the original versions of these from New Southwind a littler further down on Division st in the 90s. I'm glad to say that these are comparable and an adequate stand in for those, albeit a bit pricey. Taste is above average with good chewy texture to the rice roll and saltiness from the minced pork. Will go again.

Great place for some soulfully delicious cantonese food.  I brought enough Hak rolls & Dumplings to distribute amongst three families. Everyone raved on the taste and simple throwback to an earlier era. When foods weren't as expensive/exclusive and were satisfying to eat.  The food survived the travel up North in 90+ degree weather and was consumed within a heartbeat.
Brings back fun memories growing up in Chinatown.... Everything on the menu is delicious.

The dumplings came in a soup container and were a huge disappointment. They are more of what you would find in wonton soup. The yellow wrapper is very thick and the meat inside is extremely dense, indicating a ton of fillers. Just ordered 30 rolls.  Absolutely delicious!  You definitely need to try these Hak rolls if you've never had them before.  People that live in Chinatown buy these nonstop as breakfast, lunch or as a snack.

Rumors are the recipe was passed on from the original spot from 20 years ago. ( I can't remember the name tho). The rice rolls are 2 for $5! What a bargain! It's okay, the rolls are not super flavorful and there's not much in them. The tofu has anchovy taste so if you don't like fish taste, I wouldn't recommend.

This small place has good food. The dumplings that I like has the same taste  from an old place (Nan Fung) in Chinatown.  I also got the rice roll and stuffed tofu.  The size of the rice roll is so big and really fill you up quickly.   They are all very delicious!  I will definitely go back.

I just finish devouring my spring rice roll and got on to write this review, that's how good it is. It's been a while since I've been so inspired by the taste of something and felt the need to share it. All it was was one spring roll with scallion garnish, cold, no sauce.  At first I was thinking, this is going to be underwhelming but one bite in and I change my mind. It's beauty is that it's so simple but it packs a punch, unlike all the food out there that looks good but has no substance. Hak box did not come to play. The spring roll was so flavorful and delicious. I didn't expect it to be cold. At first I had my doubts that the rice roll texture would be too hard but it was perfect, fresh, elastic and chewy. It was filled to the max with scallions and baby shrimp and sesame on top, and with each bite all you can taste was flavor. There was no sauce, they knew how good it was and felt no need to add on a sauce to cover or enhance the taste. My only regret is that I only got one roll, but I'll def be back!!!

Picture a rainy, damp and dreary day.  Needed some good and familiar comfort food.  Took the train from Brooklyn to Manhattan's chinatown to pickup these delicious dried shrimp cheung fun rolls and 2 other items from their limited menu.  Everything was really good and fresh.  If you are craving a cantanese snack food fill then this is the place to be.  Service was friendly.  The place is a hole in the wall and expect a short wait because its a hole in wall but it's worth every delicious minutes.  Will definitely be back.

We brought 3 pieces dumplings for 4dollars, it is cold and taste so bad, doesn't feel like meat inside , doesn't have any flavor! The rice roll is also very cold, and looks dirty,  we found a stone inside of the rice roll. I don't know what is on the top of the rice roll but looks so weird.  And the rice roll is very oily! Don't try this, really not worth that price and too bad!
Great service! The flavors are on point!  Love the tofu. Will return for future good eats.

Amazing find! This restaurant, Hak Box, is a descendant from the previous family owned South Wind restaurant located on Division Street. Now located in the complex directly underneath the Manhattan Bridge on Forsyth and East Broadway. As far as I can remember, the original restaurant was in business for over 50 years. As I kid, I use to go at least twice a week because it was my comfort food. South Wind restaurant was one of the pillars in the Chinatown community. It is wonderful to find out that one of the previous employee's son is continuing the legacy with the Hak Box restaurant. The food served at Hak Box is amazing. I have to say, the food is the same as the original! I wish you guys the best! Thank you for holding on to the tradition.

I have to say the owners of this spot are very friendly and even recognize me when I've only been there twice.   They are not family of the original south wind owners but rather family friends who were taught the recipes.  So anyone who is looking to see their authenticity to south wind- is it there.

Highly recommend their rice noodle! It is one of the best I have eaten so far in the United States. It was so soft, savory and just perfect! Delicious!! I am looking forward to try their other items (tofu and dumpling) soon.

For $2.50 this is a great roll to try. This rice noodle roll is sprinkled in with sesame seeds, scallion, a bits of pieces of tuna. The rice noodle is chewy and dough like and have just the right amount of saltiness with the tuna. When I tried a chunk of the tuna alone it was a bit salty and was shocked the roll was not. Although, I recommend taking the hot sauce packet they give out as condiments because it definitely needs some type of sauce to jazz up the flavor.

It's been a year since I've been to Hak Box.  I ordered rice rolls and dumplings to see if the recipes have changed.  I think there's improvement on the rice rolls as there seems to be more flavor compared to my 1st visit.  I'd like to say thanks to Warren if an improvement was made.  I know I'll be going back more frequently.

Decided to try this since it is a few blocks away from my parents home. The food was not bad. I have eaten rice rolls most of my life and honestly these don't taste any better than the ones I have eaten before. It was good, warm, and made just right so the noodle are made just right not too soft or hard. The dumplings are a little pricey to me but they had a bit of filling in it. The shop is cute and staff are kind.

I finally got to try the food. So many times they were closed or sold out.  It's not quite South Wind restaurant which I loved and miss. The tofu is different in that they added salted fish which is tasty and good. The rice roll wasn't a hit for me. The texture of the noodle was too think and too many layers. Tasted bland, south wind used larger pieces of shrimp and silkier. It's not bad and comes close but I do miss the original recipe.

The Hal roll was disappointing in flavor as it isn't savory because the sesame oil and seeds are overpowering. It's more than double the price I get it from Ho Won. This is another one of those times I really miss South Wind.
Delicious food! Big portion and was generous with the "lew" aka garnishment and meats. Great price point for the amount of food they give. If you are in Chinatown, it is a must go to.

Charming hole-in-the-wall serving up cold rolled rice noodles topped with minced pork, dried shrimp, scallions. Perfect grab and go as a quick snack, or when you're hopping around Chinatown =]

This is what I grew up eating this is what my kids grew up eating we miss it so much since South Wind closed. Food was delicious, brought back memories.

Saw a post on FB and wanted to try this place after South Wind on Division St. closed years ago. Only 3 items offered - cheung fun roll, dumplings and tofu. Prices are higher than what you would find elsewhere but with Covid, the owner's got to make a living. The rolls are $2.50 each. These rolls were longer than what I have had elsewhere and full of meat and scallions. The dumplings are $4 for 3 dumplings. The dumplings were plump and had a lot of meat. The tofu was $5 and you get two pieces. This was cooked perfectly. Overall, the food was yummy and close to what I use to have at South Wind. With Covid hours, they open at 10AM. Closed on Mondays. The woman in front of me ordered 5 dumpling orders. When it was my turn, the owner had 2 dumpling orders left but he said he would be making more during the day. I went on a Tuesday, and got there at 10:10AM. Apparently, you can call and put in an order. i will know this the next I go. Overall, the food was delicious. A repeat visit is warranted in the future!

Hak Box brings back South Winds' favorited foods.  I tell you it is the closest thing to the real McCoy's.  The rolls are little bigger and it was filling combined with tofu and meat.  The cilantros and scallions  adds another level to the taste.

I stopped by with a few friends at the suggestion of a friend.  That friend had fond memories of the rice rolls and dumplings and thought it was just like how they grew up.  Myself, I didn't have any prior influence.  The price is cheap and food was decent but not quite something I'd go out of my way to get.

Holy cow the memories this rice noodle brought back!!!! I've been looking for an equivalent to South Wind for forever. And now, my heart is complete, I've come full circle. This is where I need to be. I would have to say it's 99% on point. You have to try this rice noodle, there is none other like it. Thank you Hak Box for coming into my life, I love you.....

Stopped by this place today and it did not disappoint!Serving old school comfort food Chinatown has been missing for quite some time... The rice rolls were on point and the and the stuff tofu bought back so many memories.  Definitely will be back for more of the rice rolls and for a taste of the dumplings soon!

A time machine to 1960's Chinatown. Nostalgia so thick in here you could cut it with a knife. The dumplings with their locally made skins pack a hefty punch of pork and shrimp. Sweet yet savory
Brings back memories from the South Winds restaurant. Taste is close. Not exactly like before. But delicious. Hope this place stays around for awhile
It's good. The guy sells three items. I bought all three to try and they're all legitimate. He doesn't use MSG. It's an acquired local taste to appreciate it but I think it's good and will go back.

I've only been here in NYC for about 5 years, so I can't compare the food to South Wind, which is being mentioned in the past reviews. I will say that the food is amazing, the Hak Roll i very much enjoyed, I was hesitant to try it cause I tend to have some issues with texture but the texture didn't bother me. It was super good. Also the dumplings were amazing... definitely a go to in the neighborhood for lunch from now on. Also try to catch them around noon! The past few days I've been wanting to try the food they've been closed because I forget the hours, they're closed by 4! Customer service was friendly and excellent as well.

Finally came here after my mom had this on her radar list after hearing that this store was homage to the original salty rice rolls on the Division St. restaurant.  The store is basically a hole in the wall with not much but 3 items (rice rolls, stuffed tofu, and dumplings).  Pretty straightforward: order, pay, and takeout.  We decided to try the rice rolls which are $2.50 a piece and the dumplings, a cup of 3 for $4.00.  The roll is descent in size, could share or engulfed by one.  It's adorned with pieces of ham, minced pork, tiny dried shrimp, scallions, and sesame seeds.  Taste wise it was find to me, but I felt it wasn't an exact to the original version (smaller individual size with simply pork and dried shrimp, the ham just seemed out of place).  But mom really enjoyed them.  As for the dumplings, the meat filling was densely packed and the skin was rubbery, because of this it didn't taste fresh.  Didn't enjoy the texture nor the taste of the dumpling, this would be a pass. Its still a descent corner spot for a quick unique Asian bite and for those nostalgic for the original spot.
Small little place but the Hak Roll is the real deal.  Reminded me of my yesteryears of having the rolls at East Wind.  Worth the trip from NJ!
Went there to try out hak roll (虾米肠). Enjoyed the food. Cozy place to take out, and they got a small table to stand there to eat too.

Chinese folks who were in this country in the 1970's through the 1990's may remember the South Wind Restaurant on Division St.  Since they closed about 15 years ago, I've been looking for a place that sold rice noodle rolls just like the comfort food sold at South Wind.  Their rice noodle rolls (called gee cheung fun) comes the closest to South Wind's.  Their stuffed tofu is identical.  Very flavorful and dripping with gravy.  I'd say it was a 100% match.  I would not be able to distinguish it apart from South Wind's (called yeung dow foo).  I have yet to try their only other offering, dumplings (called tsui gow) but I am going to return at the next opportunity.

This place really transports me to a simpler time reminiscent of childhood and when Chinatown was still Chinatown.  I though Hak rolls were gone forever replaced by shoddy factory made garbage, but thanks to Warren and team, it will live on... I make sure to visit with my kids about once a week!
Finally got my rice roll, dumpling and tofu fix! Love it!!! Will definitely go back when I am in the area again or get someone to get for me if they r in chinatown

Grew up eating the rice noodle rolls from South Wind and was so happy I can have the same deliciousness at Hak Box now. Warren, one of the co-owners, is super nice and pays attention to the preparation and presentation. Couldn't wait to have it at home so ended up devouring every morsel on the drive home. Already thinking about hitting up another order.
As us old people would say an oldie but goodie. Not open on Mondays. There's no phone number to this location

I grew up eating hakkanese food: big rice roll and big dumplings and was so excited this place opened up as there aren't many places that sell this kind of heart warming home cooking food. Place is tiny and more for take out which is perfectly fine. I bought the rice roll, dumplings and tofu w/ meat. It was so delicious and brought back great memories of happiness. The rice rolls is room temperature and had the dried shrimp, scallions and more. Absolutely filling. One dumpling was huge and comes in 3. Dumpling has scrumptious meat with delicate oyster sauce with scallions. My husband loves the tofu with meat. We bought more than enough and even though I was full, I wanted to eat another rice roll. Will definitely be back.
the noodle roll was excellent, the tofu not so great. but the noodle roll was sooo goooood

Ordered the kare kare bagnet for myself! It came with a side of regular rice. I liked how it had veggies in it, but some pieces of the meat are a bit dry since it's deep fried. It's definitely a bit on the rich side and the portion size is large so I had leftovers for another meal. My friends got the sigsig which was also pretty good, but I really liked the bagnet express my friend got! We also got the halo halo for dessert which was tasty and not too sweet. The staff were nice as well. Definitely recommend stopping by :)

!!!!!!! Whatever they are cooking up here, you can trust it is GOOD. The ingredients, the flavors, the spices are like melodious in your mouth. Even the one dish I didn't care for, I still thought was impeccable. Know what I mean? I've been here three times now and it's just awesome. I even had a fight with my boyfriend here and the food just really kept me straight. We're fine now. Probably has something to do with the chicken skin. It's magical. Anyway, 10/10. Try everything. Trust.

We shared the Shanghai lumpia as an appetizer and got the BBQ platter with 2 pork, 2 beef and 2 chicken skewers and Bagnet Express and garlic rice. The star in my humble opinion was the Bagnet Express, which basically is spicy bitesize pork belly with crispy skin, coconut milk and shrimp paste! It was so good that I licked the plate clean. The staff is very friendly and attentive. I'll definitely be back very soon!
Food was pretty good. The BBQ platter and the beef stew with bone marrow are a must. Everything was pretty affordable with good portion sizes

This is easily one of the best Fili spots in Queens. I love the Pares, creamy salty and a bit sweet of course paired by garlic rice. Sisig packed with flavors! Amazing!! The kare kare is super creamy and the umami so good, other restaurants in the area has it but I have to say they make it the best in Kalye Bistro. Good service, great food, decent prices, and a nice place to sit -- nothing not to like at Kalye Bistro. The tortang talong is a standout, and I really enjoyed the kare kare bagnet, which is super filling.

I had the chance to catch up with a friend here on a Saturday afternoon for lunch. Since moving to the area I've walked by Bacan and always admired the minimalistic decor on modern vibe you're able to distinguish solely from walking past the restaurant. I couldn't think of a better opportunity than this for a friend who had never been to Williamsburg! We made a reservation beforehand and were seated inside. When it came time to order we did a few rounds of aperol spritz's accompanied with their diavola pizza (fancy for pepperoni). Incredible atmosphere. My friend and I came to Bacàn simply due to the good atmosphere after a day of walking around Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The food was decent. I felt like the gnocchi could've had a bit more flavor and the bruschetta bread wasn't as fresh as it could've been. However, the service was good and others seemed to be enjoying their food-- so might've just been a one off experience. I liked the music they played and the dim lighting/comfortable seating

Incredible food, even better service. Jet made my girlfriend and me feel at home and took great care of us. He even surprised us with a tiramisu since he found out it was our anniversary. I'll definitely be back and HIGHLY RECOMMEND IT!

The ambience and decor is really cozy and modern but the food is expensive for the reeeaaallly small quantity you get. Although the food tastes good, it's just not mind blowing enough to justify the price.

Came here for a weeknight dinner with my wife. We shared the kale salad, the seared scallops, the cacio e pepe ravioli, and the black squid ink gnocchi. I had a couple glasses of wine including a sparkling Mongarda Prosecco and the Frug Gruner Veltliner. My favorite items were the scallops and the gnocchi. The staff was very amiable. There was one gender neutral restroom which was very spacious.

Went here last Thursday with a friend and had an amazing time! The tapas style menu is so fun to share. We had the suppli, gnocchi, uovo, tartare, polpo and taglioni - everything was so good, would 10/10 order these again.
Really nice ambience, really good food. We got iced coffee, the caprese pizza (fresh mozz and crisp focaccia), omelette (SO good), and burger. Would definitely recommend.

In one fell swoop, this place has overtaken all of our regular spots in the neighborhood. Food is incredible, traditional with a twist. Drinks are delicious and creative. And the vibe is great. Exactly what you need to get a dose of Italy while in the city whenever the urge hits. Phenomenal!
The best bacon egg and cheese sandwich in Williamsburg. Great brunch items.  No long wait like other spots in the neighborhood. Great coffee.

We moved a block away from Bacán and we feel so lucky to have found this place. You're immediately greeted by the warmth yet fun that this place exudes -- they really got it right with the decor and music. The menu is perfectly curated for shareable bites and everything is executed to perfection.  We started with this complimentary squash bite that was unexpected but was delicious nonetheless. Our server was so kind to be considerate of my dairy allergy. The polpo (octopus) was so tasty in a tomato based sauce and the pastas were plentiful and homemade. I ordered the cicchetti (smaller portion) of the pici (pesto pasta) and my partner ordered the agnolotti in the regular portion. The pici was completely vegan! The service was so attentive but what really showed was the passion this team brings to their craft. Perfect for a date night and can't wait to return.

Highly recommend this spot. I went for a glass of wine after a stressful day and felt very at ease. The staff is very charismatic with a gentle manner.
